comments.text:
Your body is constantly fighting with bacteria, if it stops doing so you 
will be eaten - alive. If you die,  protection does stop, and you will be 
eaten. (the reason i do oppose cremation, i would like that nature consumes 
me)  Some cases environment is too hostile even for bacteria, is it too dry 
or has not enough water or oxygen, and then mummification happens

top_comment.text:
Decomposition is an incredibly efficient process—as you can see up-close 
and personal in this two-camera timelapse of a decaying monitor lizard, 
shot by +Earth Unplugged. 

If you have a problem with roiling piles of maggots, though, you might want 
to give it a pass.

HT +Emily Graslie. ﻿

captions.text:
Today instead of slowing things down we're
going to be speeding things up!

Yeah we're going to be timelapsing an animal
carcass as it rots down, and if you're squeamish

look away now.
So this is the bad boy that we're decomposing

today, a bosc's monitor lizard, or a savannah
monitor. Very sadly he died of natural causes,

but then he got donated to us.
Hopefully with the timelapse we'll be able

to see exactly what happens once he starts
decomposing.

Yeah it should be really revealing.
For those of you who aren't familiar with

the timelapse, it's a process whereby you
take many still photographs over a long period

of time, so you can see something which would
conventionally take a really long time, in

a short amount of time.
So we're going to have two cameras for this,

one side on, one from the top.
So that was the decomposition of a monitor

lizard.
To see how it all began, we need to go back

to four and a half weeks ago.
There are about five basic stages of decomposition

-- we're going to have to mimic the first.
These are the decomposers we're going to be

using.
This was a chicken, but you can see its been

absolutely reduced to bones because we've
had it out probably a little bit too long.

You can see it's absolutely chocker with maggots,
fly larvae or maggots are fantastic meat eaters,

so we're going to be putting those in first.
Don't vomit through your mask.

We kind of want the initial stages, so between
0-3 days is that initial decay period, so

in here is absolutely shed loads of fly eggs
so that's perfect. We're now going to harvest

some of these fly eggs, these little larvae,
There's loads in there. When these maggots

go to work on our lizard, what are they going
to be doing?

They're one of the early starters, so they'll
be going for the dead meat. They're known

as detritovores which is basically sort of
eating dead stuff, and even faecal matter,

poo to you and me.
Cool I reckon we've got enough there. Let's

go back to mr lizard and leave this stinky
lot alone.

So I'm just about to make a few incisions
on our monitor lizard, to help out those little

fly eggs to go into and under the skin, because
that reptile skin is so solid.

Whereabouts are you going to make the incision
then?

I think I'm going to start on his belly.
Are you going to put it in a few places or

just one.
Yeah I think so, in a few places. Just about

making it through connective tissue there.
First lot of fly eggs going in. Oo there's

thousands of eggs in this one. A few a bit
further up.

So what's going to happen next?
We'll probably see it start to bloat and trigger

these fly eggs to get to it. So the fly eggs
are in mate.

He looks ready, and the cameras are ready.
Cool, so let's get it going and we'll be back

in a week to see how he's got on.
So it's been a couple of weeks since we were

here with the smelly chickens and maggots,
and to be honest I can actually smell the

lizard already.
Starting to honk a little bit

It seriously is
Let's get in there.

Right here goes.
Oh god yeah. Oh my god.

That's a wall of smell. It's changed completely
though hasn't it. The maggots have done a

great job just clearing out all the actual
tissue, it's just a bag of skin over those

bones. What would happen in the wild and what
we're going to do now is introduce some beetles,

dermestid beetles, also known as larder beetles.
OK. Time for the beetles and larvae to go

on.
They like this stage of dry decay, that's

when they come in, when the maggots ship out,
and they should strip any bits of sinew on

those bones away.
So, I reckon it's probably going to be another

week or two maybe.
Enjoy your dinner lads!

So it's been about four and a half weeks since
we put the lizard down. What do you reckon

it's going to look like Si?
Disgusting, but awesome as well. I can't wait

to see it.
Let's give it a go.

It's a bit ripe.
Oh man, oh god. There are a lot of flies in

here.
All of those little maggots turn into pupae

which turn into more flies, which leads to
more flies, it's the circle of life, it's

one dead lizard for thousands of newborns.
He's got something called beta keratin in

his skin. We don't have that and its so tough
you can see it's the only thing remaining

and even the beetles haven't got through it.
So that's kind of interesting in itself, but

I would quite like to snip away at that just
leave it with a final skeleton shot.

Yeah I'd like to see what's under that.
Cor that's a great looking skeleton.

So there you have it the decomposition of
a monitor lizard, taken over four and a half

weeks.
Make sure you subscribe to Earth Unplugged

for more amazing wonders from the natural
world.

title: Monitor Lizard Decomposition Time Lapse - Earth Unplugged
